title: Wealthy politicians identifying as farmers amid agrarian crisis in Maharashtra
desc: Many prominent Maharashtra politicians are identifying as farmers while reporting large assets in their election affidavits. This includes leaders like Chief Minister Eknath Shinde, Deputy Chief Ministers Devendra Fadnavis and Ajit Pawar, and others. Despite portraying themselves as agriculturists, they have declared assets worth crores, revealing a controversial aspect of their financial disclosures.

title: Congress government ended 'darkness' in 11 months of rule in Telangana: CM Revanth Reddy rebuts PM Modi's remark
desc: The Congress government in Telangana has transformed the state in the last 11 months. Key initiatives include free bus travel for women, a healthcare cover of Rs 10 lakhs, a massive farmer loan waiver, free electricity for women, and significant job recruitment. The government is also rejuvenating water bodies and ensuring overall development.

title: Bibek Debroy, the economist who once created a furore with proposal to tax farmers
desc: Bibek Debroy, chairman of the Economic Advisory Council to the PM, passed away at 69. Known for his advocacy to tax agricultural income, Debroy's proposals aimed to remove disparities between urban and rural taxation. His contributions spanned roles in NITI Aayog and numerous economic committees, influencing India's tax policies.

title: My statement was twisted, says DK Shivkumar after Kharge pulls up Karnataka govt
desc: DK Shivakumar retracted his remarks about possibly reviewing Karnataka's 'Shakti' scheme, which offers free bus travel to women, following criticism from Congress President Mallikarjun Kharge. Shivakumar claimed his statement was twisted and emphasized his respect for elders' decisions. The 'Shakti' scheme is part of the Congress government's initiatives in Karnataka.

title: BJP politicising issue: Karnataka Dy CM Shivakumar on Waqf land claim controversy
desc: Karnataka Chief Minister Siddaramaiah assured no farmers will be evicted amid the Waqf land controversy. Despite BJP allegations, the CM clarified that eviction notices have been withdrawn. Deputy CM DK Shivakumar accused BJP of politicizing the issue, reaffirming that farmers’ rights to their land will be protected. Home Minister G Parmeshwara confirmed the resolution of the issue.

title: Jharkhand's farmers not getting MSP on time; Hemant Soren should apologise: BJP's Himanta Biswa Sarma
desc: Assam Chief Minister and BJP co-in-charge for the Jharkhand Assembly elections, Himanta Biswa Sarma, has slammed Chief Minister Hemant Soren for his government's policies toward farmers.

title: Centre procures 60.63 lakh tonnes of paddy so far in Punjab; Rs 1,22,00 cr paid to farmers till Oct 28
desc: The Centre announced that as of October 28, 2024, it has procured 60.63 lakh tonnes of paddy in Punjab, disbursing Rs 12,200 crore to farmers. With a target of 185 lakh tonnes for Kharif Marketing Season 2024-25, the procurement began on October 1, with 2,927 mandis operational across the state.

title: We will withdraw notices, says Siddaramaiah on Waqf Board’s claims over farmland
desc: Chief Minister Siddaramaiah assured farmers in Vijayapura, Yadgir and Dharwad that no one will be evicted from their land and any issued notices will be withdrawn. He accused the BJP of spreading misinformation and clarified that no notices claiming farmland as Waqf property were issued under the current government. BJP has pledged to fight for farmers' rights.

title: Paddy procurement: Punjab farmers decide to lift road blockade
desc: Farmers protesting in Punjab over slow paddy procurement have decided to lift blockades from four highways after a meeting with Punjab ministers. While the roadside sit-in continues, the state assured that paddy lifting will be sped up and farmers will be compensated for losses below MSP.

title: Punjab: Farmers continue their protest for second day, demand paddy procurement among others
desc: Farmers in Punjab continue their protest for the second day, demanding paddy procurement and sufficient supplies of DAP fertilizer. The protests, organized by Kisan Mazdoor Sangharsh Committee and Sanyukta Kisan Morcha, included roadblocks in several locations, while discussions with authorities and political figures are ongoing.

title: Punjab: Farmers to hold 'chakka jam' in 4 locations over demands,including paddy procurement
desc: Farmers in Punjab started a sit-down protest in Kapurthala demanding timely paddy procurement. Organised by Bharatiya Kisan Union (Krantikari) Punjab, they plan to block national highways if their demands are not met. The issue was discussed in a New Delhi meeting with Union Food and Supply Minister and continues to be significant for the protesting farmers.

title: Facing labour shortage, rural economy & food security on Chinese radar
desc: China's agriculture ministry has issued guidelines for provincial governments to enhance farmers' income and promote employment in rural areas. These measures include developing new agriculture businesses, such as cooperatives and family farms, and supporting resource contracting and property leasing. The state aims to address labor shortages in farms and improve food security.

title: 'Tardy' paddy procurement: Farmers to block roads at few places in Punjab on Saturday
desc: Farmers in Punjab, led by Kisan Mazdoor Morcha's Sarwan Singh Pandher, plan to initiate an indefinite road blockade from October 26 to protest against slow paddy procurement, inadequate DAP fertiliser supplies, and penalties for stubble burning. The protests will occur in Sangrur, Moga, Phagwara, and Batala.

title: Ready go to for jail for the sake of farmers: BRS leader K T Rama Rao
desc: KT Rama Rao criticized Congress and BJP for not fulfilling election promises at a farmers' rally in Adilabad. He pledged to fight for farmers, even if it means going to jail. Rama Rao highlighted unfulfilled promises like the revival of CCI plant, financial aid to farmers, and job creation, stating there's no difference between Congress and BJP.

title: Scientists suggest ways to Odisha paddy farmers for minimising loss due to cyclone Dana
desc: Agriculture scientists in Odisha suggest measures to minimise paddy crop damage due to cyclone Dana's heavy rain. Eight coastal districts likely to be affected. Farmers are advised to keep drainage channels open, properly stack and cover harvested rice, dry grains after rain, and use fumigation for storage pests.

title: Consumers face the heat with cooking oil on the boil
desc: Consumers in India are paying more for cooking oils like mustard, soyabean, and palm oil as demand rises due to Diwali. India increased import duties on these oils to support soybean prices. However, soybean prices remain below the minimum support price levels, affecting farmers and the edible oil industry.

title: Stubble burning incidents: Haryana suspends 24 agriculture dept officials
desc: Haryana's Agriculture and Farmers' Welfare Department has suspended 24 officials for failing to prevent stubble burning. The Supreme Court has criticized Haryana and Punjab for inadequate action on the issue, linking it to rising pollution in the national capital. Legal and administrative measures are being enforced.

title: Machinery should be given at subsidized rates and sold to cooperative sectors: Farmer leader Prem Singh Bhangu
desc: Farmer leaders in Haryana say they are forced to burn stubble due to lack of subsidized machinery. They demand subsidized equipment and compensation for not burning stubble. They argue that the government blames them for pollution without providing adequate solutions. Air quality in Delhi remains poor, with ongoing criticism from political leaders.

title: Congress MP Surjewala slams Haryana Govt's handling of stubble burning issue
desc: Congress MP Randeep Singh Surjewala criticizes the Haryana BJP government for its policies against farmers, questioning stubble burning alternatives and MSP abolition. He challenges the accessibility of costly Happy Seeder Machines and warns of a nationwide movement if policies aren't retracted.

title: Opposition MVA releases 'traitors record' against BJP-led Maharashtra govt
desc: The Opposition Maha Vikas Aghadi labels the ruling Mahayuti in Maharashtra as a government that favors the rich and neglects the poor. They highlight increased prices, high GST on essential items, lack of support for farmers, and corruption, urging voters to reject the current administration.

title: Indian farmers get just one-third of the price we pay for fruits and vegetables
desc: Indian farmers earn only about one-third of the final selling price for fruits and vegetables. Research suggests enhancing private markets, using e-NAM, and promoting farmer collectives to address this. Building cold storage and improving processing capacities are also advised. For dairy and poultry sectors, creating feed banks and promoting artificial insemination can boost productivity.

title: Haryana assembly elections: Farmers'protests could have been handled better, says Rao Inderjit Singh
desc: Union minister Rao Inderjit Singh is campaigning vigorously for the Haryana assembly elections, promoting his daughter Arti Rao and other candidates he recommended. Singh, who switched from Congress to BJP in 2014, is seen as a potential CM candidate. He addresses farmer protests and BJP rebels contesting as Independents.

title: Kangana Ranaut does U-turn on comments on farm laws, BJP distances itself, Congress seeks action
desc: BJP MP Kangana Ranaut retracted her call to reinstate the repealed farm laws, sparking controversy. The BJP distanced itself from her remarks, while the Congress demanded her expulsion and an explanation from PM Modi. The issue arises amid Haryana's election campaign, where protests against these laws were prominent.

title: 'Are you up to some mischief': Rahul Gandhi asks PM Modi to clarify stand on Kangana's remark on farm laws
desc: Rahul Gandhi criticized the BJP over MP Kangana Ranaut's remarks on reviving the three farm laws, demanding Prime Minister Narendra Modi clarify his stance. Ranaut later withdrew her comments, stating they were personal opinions. Gandhi warned that any attempt to revive the laws would face opposition from the INDIA bloc, emphasizing respect for the farmers who protested against them.

title: Kangana Ranaut says views on farm laws personal amid backlash
desc: BJP MP Kangana Ranaut clarified that her views on reinstating the repealed farm laws are personal and do not reflect the party's stance. The Himachal Pradesh BJP distanced itself from her statement. Ranaut made these remarks at an event in Mandi, emphasizing the benefits of the laws for farmers' financial stability and growth.

title: Country now knows BJP is anti-farmer mindset: Mallikarjun Kharge after Kangana Ranaut's remark on farm laws
desc: Congress president Mallikarjun Kharge criticized the BJP over MP Kangana Ranaut's call to reinstate the repealed farm laws. Ranaut later retracted her statement, expressing regret. Kharge accused the Modi government of being anti-farmer and failing to fulfill promises made to farmers. He asserted that poll-bound states like Haryana would respond strongly to these remarks.

title: Haryana assembly polls: Elections to pivot around jobs, farmer protests, agniveer & Dalit votes
desc: Haryana is the first state to hold elections after the Lok Sabha polls, with Congress and BJP both having won five seats each. The state's political landscape is influenced by caste dynamics, farmer protests, and unemployment. Both parties are focusing on consolidating their vote bases, with Dalit votes seen as crucial this time.

title: My three generations never paid farm electricity bills: Shiv Sena MP
desc: Union minister Prataprao Jadhav revealed that his family has not paid farm electricity bills for three generations. Speaking at an event for the Chief Minister Baliraja Free Electricity Scheme 2024, he mentioned giving money to engineers to replace burnt distribution panels. The scheme offers free electricity to farmers using pumps up to 7.5 horsepower.

title: Focus on youth, women, poor and farmers: PM Modi
desc: Prime Minister Narendra Modi celebrated his 74th birthday in Odisha, marking 100 days of his third term by launching the Subhadra scheme for women's welfare and other projects. He emphasized that youth, women, poor, and farmers are central to his policies. Modi also inaugurated development projects worth thousands of crores and highlighted major decisions for the welfare of various sections of society.
